It is exceedingly silly to take oneself seriously. It results in
over-indulgence, stomach ulcers, fights, and other, damaging
things. That is why the News-Letter, on long tradition, never takes
itself seriously. We are of course concerned with the success or
failure of campus activities. We do try very seriously, despite
the comments of our detractors, to improve conditions here and to
aid any and all of the various parts of Hopkins. This we consider part of our duty to the school not as newspaper editors but as
undergraduates. But by and large, we see something humorous,
or perhaps ludicrous, in most of what goes on here. This is what
we mean when we say we never take ourselves seriously.
When the Newl-Letter. sees a dance collapse completely,
•
when somebody's bright idea of an atomic explosion results in a
large fishnet falling•on the bandstand, trapping a dozen musicians
in the eonfusion, it strikes us as about 20% tragedy and 80%
comedy. When they play the National Anthem at a football game,
and 19 players face the flag and 3 face the players bench, that's
100% comedy. When we dig up an old family, joke about "back
to Moscow," and 100 people think we mean some organization
on campus is a communist front, that's about 50-50. And when we
write a headline that completely distorts a story, it's still about
20% funny, although we earnestly try to keep that sort of
thing from happening.
When we write an editorial criticising an organization for
not being as good as it might be, and suggesting that they take
a new look at themselves or quit, we mean it, very seriously.
But still we would be shocked to a temporary loss of words
if they quit. We are happy to see that the Booster Club did not
quit. In fact, and herein lies the comedy, they had already started
towards a new definition of their activities when they told us they
were sponsoring a tour through Johns Hopkins Hospital, and we
were forted to print this information on page one while we
criticised them for not doing that sort of thing on page five.

By TOM STONE, Sports Editor
Re-Emphasis At Hopkins Not De-Emphasis

It has been brought to the attention of this writer by Marshall
TiIrner, Director of Athletics of The Hopkins, that our athletic
. program,is one of re-emphasis not one of de-emphasis as this Nester
persists in calling it.
Re-emphasis in this context is a new word to many of our
ears and eyes. Publicists of our program and similar programs
have almost automatically referred to them as programs of
de-emphasis. There are varied opinions on the meanings of these
words concerning emphasis. As for de-emphasis, it is used in
referring to the act of ceasing to stress athletics in numerous
degrees. The administrators of our policy take one of the extreme
degrees in considering it to mean to cease so far that it brings
about abandoning the intercollegiate athletic field and engaging
exclusively in intramural sports. Since the administrators claim
not to think along these lines, they refute the using of the word
de-emphasis in referring to The Hopkins athletic policy, for
logical reasons.
Aims
However, the word re-emphasis in the mind of The Nester
means to place former emphasis on something. If that is a universal
meaning of the word, does that mean that Hopkins is attempting
to return to the athletic heights it attained prior to the initiation
of the present policy some twenty years ago. By no means is it the
plan of the administrators for this university to return to the
status it held on the athletic fields in those days. Instead, according
to Mr. Turner, the aims of the program are (1) to put athletics
in the proper place of the university program and, (2) to place
proper emphasis on such in an educational institution such as ours.
In explaining their use of the word re-emphasis, Mr. Turner stated:
"Re-emphasis to us means emphasizing athletics, but only in its
proper place in the educational program."

It is exceedingly silly to take oneself seriously. It results in
over-indulgence, stomach ulcers, fights, and other, damaging
things. That is why the News-Letter, on long tradition, never takes
itself seriously. We are of course concerned with the success or
failure of campus activities. We do try very seriously, despite
the comments of our detractors, to improve conditions here and to
aid any and all of the various parts of Hopkins. This we consider part of our duty to the school not as newspaper editors but as
undergraduates. But by and large, we see something humorous,
or perhaps ludicrous, in most of what goes on here. This is what
we mean when we say we never take ourselves seriously.
When the Newl-Letter. sees a dance collapse completely,
•
when somebody's bright idea of an atomic explosion results in a
large fishnet falling•on the bandstand, trapping a dozen musicians
in the eonfusion, it strikes us as about 20% tragedy and 80%
comedy. When they play the National Anthem at a football game,
and 19 players face the flag and 3 face the players bench, that's
100% comedy. When we dig up an old family, joke about "back
to Moscow," and 100 people think we mean some organization
on campus is a communist front, that's about 50-50. And when we
write a headline that completely distorts a story, it's still about

By TOM STONE, Sports Editor
Re-Emphasis At Hopkins Not De-Emphasis

It has been brought to the attention of this writer by Marshall
TiIrner, Director of Athletics of The Hopkins, that our athletic
. program,is one of re-emphasis not one of de-emphasis as this Nester
persists in calling it.
Re-emphasis in this context is a new word to many of our
ears and eyes. Publicists of our program and similar programs
have almost automatically referred to them as programs of
de-emphasis. There are varied opinions on the meanings of these
words concerning emphasis. As for de-emphasis, it is used in
referring to the act of ceasing to stress athletics in numerous
degrees. The administrators of our policy take one of the extreme
degrees in considering it to mean to cease so far that it brings
about abandoning the intercollegiate athletic field and engaging
exclusively in intramural sports. Since the administrators claim
not to think along these lines, they refute the using of the word
de-emphasis in referring to The Hopkins athletic policy, for
logical reasons.
Aims
However, the word re-emphasis in the mind of The Nester
means to place former emphasis on something. If that is a universal
meaning of the word, does that mean that Hopkins is attempting
to return to the athletic heights it attained prior to the initiation
of the present policy some twenty years ago. By no means is it the
plan of the administrators for this university to return to the
status it held on the athletic fields in those days. Instead, according
to Mr. Turner, the aims of the program are (1) to put athletics
in the proper place of the university program and, (2) to place
proper emphasis on such in an educational institution such as ours.
In explaining their use of the word re-emphasis, Mr. Turner stated:
"Re-emphasis to us means emphasizing athletics, but only in its
proper place in the educational program."

it became the first organization of its kind and size to formulate
and adopt an exacting athletic policy. According to Mr. Manning
M. Pattillo, Associate Secretary Commission on Colleges and Universities of the Association:"The principle underlying this policy
is that the essential difference between a good athletic program
and a bad athletic program is a difference in purpose." Mr.
Pattillo continued by saying that "since colleges and universities

is one, like Hopkins, which seems to be lacking something. It is
the hope of this editor that our fault may be uncovered in a very
careful comparison of these programs with the,one in use at The
Hopkins today. It is for this reason that the Nester has decided
to devote his column for the next few weeks or so to a careful
comparison of the various segments of the programs. Next week
